clues.text: The wrist bones of this "bear" are elongated & act as thumbs for holding bamboo stalks
Besides smaller ears, this species of elephant has smaller tusks & fewer ribs
This weasel-like animal related to the polecat has long been used to drive out rabbits & rats
This kind of monkey is named for its long nose to which it honks for attention
The ring-tailed variety of this primate shows aggression with spat-calls & stink fights
After the flood Noah's dove returned with a leaf, not a branch, of this tree
It's thought the pottage for which this biblical figure sold his birthright was made of lentils
The printers of a 1631 Bible were fined 300 pounds for leaving this word out of the 7th Commandment
The 12 different gemstones on Aaron's breastplate represented these
The King James version calls this the Salt Sea
Newsweek called this author of "Clear and Present Danger", "the king of techno-thrillers"
One-word title of the DuBose Heyward novel that became a play & Gershwin opera
He wrote "Public Speaking and Influencing Men in Business" several years before his most famous book
Middle-earth creator whose middle names were Ronald & Reuel
Archaeologist who published his 3-volume work "The Tomb of Tutankhamun" between 1923 & 1933
In the 1920s, the tomb of his mother Hetepheres was found near his Great Pyramid
This last empress of Russia was born in Darmstadt in 1872, her father was Grand Duke of Hesse-Darmstadt
She outlived her husband by 60 years, but suffered periods of insanity
Crown Prince Rudolf of this country was found shot to death at Mayerling in 1889
Charlemagne was a member of this Frankish dynasty, also known as the Arnulfinger Dynasty
Schubertiaden were parties held in homes in this capital city to listen to Schubert's music
1 of the 3 Shakespearean characters for whom Giuseppe Verdi titled an opera
This name was given to "Symphony in G" because of a loud chord that Haydn said "would make ladies jump"
The "Tosca" composer who said he was a "mighty hunter of wild fowl, opera librettos & attractive women"
In 1708, the Mühlhausen city council paid for printing "Gott ist mein König", his first published music
The great lakes of this continent includes Lakes Nyasa, Albert & Victoria
The lowlands of this country invaded by China in 1950 are over 12,000 feet above sea level
The Guernsey & Jersey breeds of cattle originated in this island group
Pliny the Elder was killed by the eruption of this volcano on the Bay of Naples in 79 A.D.
4,741-foot Puig Major is the highest point on this Spanish Mediterranean island
"Rhapsody In Blue"
The "1812 Overture"
"The Blue Danube" set sail Feb. 15, 1867
"Carmen" comes alive in 1875
"Tristan und Isolde", with the help of King Ludwig
You're just getting by if you're on a budget that mentions this footwear fastener
Casinos use multiple-deck cardholders called shoes to combat card counters at this game
Pressing a certain car pedal pushes these shoes against the inside of the drum
This dreamy style of British indie rock got its name from the way performers stared at their effects pedals
Eyewitnesses differ as to whether this Soviet premier actually banged his shoe on a desk at a 1960 U.N. meeting
The principal, to Janine on this ABC sitcom: "Step was my thing in college! It certainly wasn't academics. I hate school"

As Oliver, Martin Short has a shocking revelation on this Hulu show:
"Rock icon Sting is a dog-poisoning murderer"
This sitcom's Dr. Spaceman, delivering Tracy some tough news: "I don't know how to say this... D.A. but eez?"
Noho Hank, to this title guy wanting off work: "What do you want me to do? Go to John Wick Assassin Hotel with help wanted sign?"
Darius, on this FX show: "I would say nice to meet you but I don't believe in time as a concept. So I'll just say we always met"
Olivia Newton-John's first U.S. No. 1 hit included this adverb for how she loved you
This kind of truth alludes to one of the narratives that begin the New Testament
If something is the real deal, it's the this article, from Latin for "innate"
This synonym of "definitive" begins with a synonym of "writer"
Verb meaning to verify an article pre-publication; before .org, it's a nonpartisan project to evaluate what politicians say
Naturally, it's the title song as Gene Kelly & Frank Sinatra play old-time baseball players

clues.text: "The Sound Of Silence" is heard in the opening of this 1967 film
This future "Masked Singer" competitor sang the theme from "Ghostbusters"
He crooned "Wicked Game", featured in David Lynch's "Wild at Heart"
"Diamond Girl" is on the '70s-heavy soundtrack of this 2021 film with a title that describes an LP
Old French for "daily" gives us this type of register in which events of the day are recorded
This snoop who overhears a conversation is named for part of a roof
Greeks called this beast megas strouthos, "big sparrow", or strouthokamelos, "sparrow-camel"; we know it as this
This word comes from the Hindi for "massage"; it's more familiar as a sudsy shower substance
This first portion of the small intestine is named for its length of about 12 fingerbreadths

rounds.text: 1st given in 1969, it's the only Nobel Prize category added since awards began in 1901
